stem: The nurse is preparing to irrigate a client's ear to remove impacted cerumen. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Position the client with the head tilted toward the affected ear with a basin underneath.
Warm the irrigation solution to body temperature (approx. 98.6Â°F).
Instruct the client to remain side-lying for several minutes to allow drainage.
Assess the ear canal with an otoscope to ensure the tympanic membrane is intact.
Straighten the ear canal and direct the fluid stream toward the upper wall of the canal.

rationale.correct: Ear irrigation requires care to prevent injury or vertigo. (1) Contraindication check: NEVER irrigate if the eardrum is perforated. (2) Cold or hot fluid will cause severe vertigo and vomiting (Caloric stimulation). (3) Gravity assist. (4) Directing the stream to the wall (not the wax) allows the water to go behind the wax and push it out. (5) Drainage.
rationale.incorrect: Directing the water stream directly at the cerumen (wax) can push it deeper or puncture the tympanic membrane.
clinicalPearls: Stop the procedure immediately if the client becomes dizzy, nauseated, or reports severe pain.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Off-Center'. Aim for the canal roof, not the wax ball itself.

reviewUnits.heading: Assessment and Care of the Auditory System
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for hearing loss and teach clients not to use cotton swabs to clean the inside of the ear canal.
